Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement: The Neuroendocrine & Neurobiological Bases of Complex Social Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent scientific advances in our understanding of the forces shaping social behavior have been driven by growing appreciation of the influence of hormones, especially the neuropeptides oxytocin (OXT) and arginine vasopressin (AVP). These hormones are being implicated as essential mechanisms in shaping a range of affiliative and aggressive social relationships and behavior, including pair-bonding, territoriality, parenting, and cooperation. Fully comprehensive understanding of how these hormones function could provide not only knowledge of the organization of social life, but also therapeutic benefits to organisms, including humans, with social impairments. Research into oxytocin and vasopressin utilizing rodent models has begun to suggest potential treatments for several human conditions, including autism spectrum disorders, social anxiety, and schizophrenia. While these studies provide essential data on the roles of hormones such as OXT and AVP, they are limited by the fact that they focus on animals with social systems characterized by less complexity and richness, relative to those of our species. With the goal of more thoroughly investigating the roles that these hormones play in mediating complex social behavior, this dissertation research by doctoral student Daniel Coppeto (under the supervision of Dr. James Rilling, Emory University) will utilize anthropological and neuroscientific approaches to linking hormones and social behavior in two primates with complex, yet differing social systems.

This project will advance the study of how oxytocin and vasopressin mediate complex social relationships by investigating the roles that these hormones play in the social lives of two types of baboons with vastly differing societies, the hamadryas and the anubis baboon. Like humans, baboons display a range of sociality and intricate social structures, and as such, present a unique opportunity to employ an animal model with enhanced relevance to understanding the phenomenon in our own species. To test the hypothesis that these contrasting societies can be understood through assessing the roles of oxytocin and vasopressin, this project will first collect biological samples to measure oxytocin and vasopressin levels utilizing enzyme immunoassays, comparing these between the two subspecies. By then linking the hormonal data to observations of social behavior of the subjects within social groups of each subspecies, the project will provide a highly contextualized understanding of how OXT and AVP mold sociality. These will be complemented through neurobiological examination of how oxytocin and vasopressin receptors are distributed in the brain, as differences in the pattern of brain hormone receptors are a common avenue by which these hormones may affect behavior.

The results of this research will have impacts across several dimensions, from basic science and education, to potential therapeutic translation. While this project will show how oxytocin and vasopressin are integral to shaping primate societies, it also will demonstrate in appropriate animal models how these forces are capable of influencing our own behavior. Likewise, an analysis of how these hormones operate in primates will provide insight into how they can potentially be refined for usage in therapy for a range of human social disorders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project sought to better describe and understand how hormones and the brain control the unique social systems between the different subspecies of baboons. In particular, this study wanted to focus on the importance of the hormones oxytocin and vasopressin, whose roles in social behavior have been so well described in other animals, but have yet to be well-understood in primates. Both oxytocin and vasopressin have been found to be essential hormones in the control of prosocial behaviors including mate bonding. Similarly, the hamadryas and the anubis baboon have been found to differ exactly in these ways, with the hamadryas baboon forming durable mate bonds while the anubis baboon continues to mate promiscuously.

 

            Thus, although this project would initially appear to have little influence on human life, the results of this research are actually of great interest to the public. Research on oxytocin and vasopressin in rodents has already transformed our understanding of their function in human social behavior, and has even provided insight into possible therapies for individuals suffering from social disorders.

 

            This project had three primary aims:

1. To compare the levels of oxytocin and vasopressin between hamadryas and anubis baboons.

2. To compare the levels of oxytocin and vasopressin within hamadryas and anubis baboons and connect these levels to differences in social behavior.

3. To compare the distribution and density of the receptors for these hormones in the brains of hamadryas and anubis baboons.

 

            Although this project is not entirely complete, it has progressed very far, and has already produced results that are of interest to academics and the public alike.

 

            Aim 1: All of the hormones have been collected from both baboon species and are currently being analyzed to determine their differences.

 

            Aim 2: All behavioral data has been collected and is currently being analyzed. Thus far, this project has found that both baboon species continue to produce their species-specific behaviors even in captivity. These observations continue to suggest that the control of these social behaviors are probably genetic, and most likely represented differently in both the brains and hormones of the two baboon species.

 

            Aim 3: Several brain have been collected, and many have already been processed and are ready to have their receptor differences analyzed. 

 

This project is almost complete, and will soon have definitive answers to these questions. The observations thus far that demonstrate the persistence of these unique behaviors, even in unusual captive conditions, goes to further suggest that the results of the hormone and brain aims will reinforce this finding. Once these results have been analyzed, it will then be possible to better understand how these hormones operate in the bodies and brains of primates. It is the hope of this study that these results will provide additional clues which can be translated into viable therapeutic advances for individuals suffering from a variety of social disorders.

 

The goals of this project were to: 1) Understand teh roles of the neuropeptides oxytocin (OT) and vasopressin (AVP) in explaining individual differences in bonding and social behavior between two different baboon species (anubis and hamadryous), 2) Understand the roles of the neuropeptide hormones OT and AVP in explaining variation in bonding and sociality within each of these two primate species, and 3) Understand how differences in teh distribution anddensity of neural receptors for OT and AVP mediate species differences in behavior related to primate bonding and sociality.
